para:
A Bunge object represents the orientation of a three dimensional object, assumed to be a crystal, in three dimensional space in terms of three angles,
\(\phi_1\) ,
\(\Theta\) , and \(\phi_2\) , corresponding to rotations which bring the lab (or screen) axes &xhat;, &yhat;, and &zhat; into coincidence with the crystalline &ahat;, &bhat;, and &chat;, axes, respectively. This is the conventional usage of the texture community, and is the opposite of the usual sense for rotations in &oof2;.

With this important difference, it resembles the convention, in that the axis selection and ordering are the same. The \(\phi_1\)
rotation is about the initial laboratory axis &zhat;, the second
\(\Theta\)
rotation is about the rotated laboratory &xhat; axis, and the third
\(\phi_2\)
rotation is about the rotated &zhat; axis.

The &oof2; implementation of this method actually constructs the usual &oof2; rotation matrix (which takes the crystalline axes into the laboratory axes), but does so from the conventionally specified Bunge parameters. Users familiar with the Bunge convention can thus use previously obtained or instrument provided angles directly.
